prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong in this situation. The scenario is about a couple living together where the author is paying all the bills because the girlfriend only works part-time. The incident that triggered this is the author making the girlfriend pay for takeout that cost under $40. The author is now considering making her start paying some bills because of this.

First, I need to look at the dynamics here. The author is upset about the girlfriend's reaction to paying for takeout. He feels he's been paying everything, which might have created an unspoken expectation. The girlfriend works part-time, so her income is lower, but the author suggests that even a small amount could help. The key points are communication, fairness, and mutual expectations in a relationship.

The author is considering a significant change (making her pay more) based on a single incident. This could be seen as overreacting. Relationships often require discussion and compromise. Maybe the author should have talked to her about splitting costs instead of making an abrupt change. Also, the way the author framed the situation might show a lack of empathy—acknowledging her financial limitations and addressing the emotional reaction (her "ugly attitude") without understanding the root cause.

On the other hand, the author has been covering all expenses, which might be unfair in the long run. The girlfriend might not be contributing as much as expected, leading to resentment. The author's desire for her to "carry her weight" could be valid, but the approach here is problematic. Instead of reacting to a single incident, discussing shared responsibilities and financial planning would be more constructive.

So, the author is acting out of frustration from a minor issue but is considering a major shift in financial responsibility. This might not be fair unless there's a broader conversation about their financial arrangements. The author's inconsiderate approach and lack of communication could make him the one at fault here. Therefore, the answer is A (Yes, the author is in the wrong).
